head.title: Pistons Find Adubato's Magic Tough to Beat

Magic 93, Pistons 84

Anfernee Hardaway scored 29 points and the host Orlando Magic remained unbeaten under their interim coach, Richie Adubato, ending the Detroit Pistons' six-game winning streak with a 93-84 victory last night.
The Magic improved to 4-0 since Adubato replaced Brian Hill, who was fired last week.

Hardaway atoned for a poor performance in a road loss at Detroit on Feb. 12 by shooting 11 for 16 from the field, including 4 of 6 from behind the 3-point arc. Rony Seikaly was the only other player in double figures for Orlando, finishing with 19 points and 8 rebounds.
Theo Ratliff led Detroit with 17 points. Grant Hill, who had a triple-double the last time the teams played, struggled with 14 points this time.
Hardaway, just 3 of 15 from the field in Orlando's loss to the Pistons earlier in the month, had 18 points and the Magic shot 57 percent in building a 56-39 halftime lead.
The Magic have limited opponents to 86 points per game under Adubato.
Bulls 116, Trail Blazers 89
Michael Jordan scored 30 of his 37 points in the first half as Chicago extended its winning streak to seven games.
Scottie Pippen added 22 points, 11 assists and 9 rebounds for the Bulls, who are 49-6 over all and 26-1 at the United Center. They have won 19 consecutive home games.
The last time the teams met, Feb. 4 in Portland, Jordan scored 22 fourth-quarter points as the Bulls rallied for an 88-84 victory. This time, Jordan took care of things early.
After the reserves Steve Kerr, Toni Kukoc and Jason Caffey helped Chicago take a 53-39 lead, Jordan scored the Bulls' final 14 points of the first half to make it 67-49.
He made three fade-away jumpers, a bank shot, a 3-pointer, a layup and a free throw during his spree. He scored over Marcus Brown, Stacey Augmon, Cliff Robinson and Rumeal Robinson.
Hawks 106, Warriors 100

Christian Laettner scored 25 points and Mookie Blaylock just missed a triple-double for Atlanta. Blaylock finished with 18 points, 9 rebounds and 8 assists as the Hawks won for the 23d time in 25 home games.
Laettner hit a jumper to give the Hawks a 98-96 lead with 2 minutes 30 seconds left. Then Blaylock took over, scoring 4 points and making 2 steals for the Hawks down the stretch.
Hornets 96, Spurs 84
Glen Rice scored 33 points as the visiting Hornets extended their winning streak to a season-best five games. Charlotte has won 10 of its last 12 games.
Anthony Mason added 24 points and 16 rebounds for Charlotte.
